wikipedia_page.main:
Charles Hotson Ebden (1811 – 28 October 1867) was an Australian pastoralist and politician, a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council, the 
Victorian Legislative Council and the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

response: Among the first squatters to follow in the steps of the explorers and settle in the district were William Wyse and Charles Ebden.

The suburb was named after Black Rock House, a grand residence built by Charles Ebden in 1856, who had taken the name from Black Rock, Dublin. Ebden was an early Port Phillip pastoralist as well as being a businessman and parliamentarian representing the seat of Brighton in the Victorian Parliament. Black Rock House is on the Register of the National Estate.

In the same way that Ripponlea took its name from the Rippon Lea Estate of Sir Frederick Sargood, Elsternwick took its name from the largest property in the district: Charles Ebden's house Elster (Elster is German for "").[https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/168732614 Victorian Place Names Truth 30 November 1913 page 9 The area was previously known as Red Bluff.

The station was originally part of the Melbourne & Hobson's Bay United Railway Company's network. The company and network was taken over by the Government of Victoria in 1878, to become part of Victorian Railways. As with the suburb Ripponlea, which had been named after the adjacent "Rippon Lea Estate" of Frederick Sargood, Elsternwick had been named after the largest property in the district, Charles Ebden's "Elster".Elster was German for "magpie". The creek nearby became known as the Elster Creek and, when a village grew up on the creek, the Anglo-Saxon suffix ‘wick’, meaning village, was added.

Major Thomas Mitchell, New South Wales Surveyor General crossed and named the Campaspe River near present-day Kyneton on his 1836 expedition.Shire of Campaspe ; retrieved 7 January 2010. Charles Ebden was the first European occupier of the region that included the Kyneton townsite. He set up a head station for his sheep run at Carlsruhe, Victoria 6 km South of Kyneton on the 26th May 1837.Walker, Thomas, A Month in the Bush of Australia, J. Crook, London, 1838, p. 34

link_mentions.page: St Kilda and Brighton Railway Company
response: In November 1853, a bill was introduced in the Parliament of Victoria for incorporation of a company to be called the "Melbourne, St. Kilda and Brighton Railway Company". Then, in December 1855, it was announced that another bill would be presented to Parliament to incorporate the "St. Kilda and Brighton Railway Company". Charles Ebden was chairman of directors of the company.
